dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ragnar emerges from his house carrying the baby, wrapped blanket. The storm has passed. The wood and turf building one of several in the small hamlet perched on the edge of deep fjord. It’s a vision of stillness and utter tranquillity. The thickly wooded slopes of the fyord drop down sheer to the water, and above them the bare rocks ar still capped with snow. The whole landscape has a strange magical luminosity - a heightened, almost unnatural beaut Ragnar takes his son to the water’s edge and holds him ou his arms, like an offering.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Look Odin. Look, I have a son. Thank you, lord. Thank you for my son. We move in CLOSE on the baby’s face - then the camera til up towards the sky. And suddenly the sky begins to darken...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkness - and out of the darkness a noise like no other, horns and hooves and the shrill cry of birds and the roar of men and women. And over the dark fields, fringed with fire, high in the darkling sky flies a tumultuous host: thousands of Viking warriors and Valkyries packed togethe and riding plunging horses, armed with spears and swords, half-naked shield-maidens with bows and shields, sweeping across the heavens in a wild hunt amidst thick flocks of wheeling ravens. And in the midst of this vast ghostly army the huge figur Odin, the god of dead warriors, lord of Valhalla, riding eight-legged horse Sleipnir, carrying his spear, two rave perched on his shoulders, his cloak streaming out behind his single-eye surveying this great, ecstatic, thundering host of the risen dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winter. The embers of the fire still glow in the centre o the floor. We are close again on the baby’s face...as he sleeps in the crook of Ragnar’s arm. Ragnar is awake, staring up into the darkness and the pla shadows across the rafters, a look of profound awe upon h face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now everything is in the fierce grip of the deepest winte Icy winds blast across the fjord, heaping the water into wild, foaming waves, and the mountains above are thick wi snow. Even at mid-day the sky is almost dark, like a perpetual twilight. But through this dark desolation a solitary FIGURE can be seen, a black smudge against the snow, wrapped in furs against the icy winds, struggling towards the hamlet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lagertha plays with her two CHILDREN. Her son BJORN is ab ten and daughter GYDA about eight years old. Ragnar appears, gestures to her.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Come. Ragnar leads Lagertha into the main room. RAGNAR (CONT’D) Here is the man I told you of, Lagertha. He indicates the figure standing beside the fire: a tall of uncertain age, his craggy face heavily lined, his hair beard both long and matted, as if his journey has been lo and arduous.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: Welcome, stranger, to our house. The strange man bows a little. Lagertha pours a drink of sweet, strong mead and hands it to him. The stranger empt the cup.  LAGERTHA (CONT’D) Sit by the fire, warm yourself. The stranger nods again, and sits, Ragnar and Lagertha do likewise.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: This man is a wanderer. He has been on a boat that travelled to the west. This is clearly a shock to Lagertha. She stares at the ma

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: Is it true? Once more the stranger nods, but does not reply. Lagertha suddenly realizes that he is glancing towards his cup, an she quickly re-fills it. And once more he empties it, then belches, and wipes his over his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: WANDERER
dialogues.text: We sailed north up the coast, to the rock formation which looks like a skull. And then, when we were out in the open sea, we turned due west. And I was frightened.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: What happened to you? Where did you get to? Behind her, we see Bjorn and Gyda peeking into the room, listening.

dialogues.speaker: WANDERER
dialogues.text: After two days and nights we saw land. Someone said it was a land called England, for they had been there before. But I don’t know if it’s true. I was only told that in this land there was great treasure. We went ashore, found a big house there, and took some things from it. From his bundle of discarded furs he retrieves an object: small but very beautiful ivory crucifix.  WANDERER (CONT’D) In England, they worship a strange god called Jesus Christ. They say he died in a tree.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Like Odin. Only Odin came back to life. Lagertha examines the glittering prize.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell us how you crossed the open ocean - once you lost sight of land? How did you know you were sailing west, not north or south?

dialogues.speaker: WANDERER
dialogues.text: We had a board. It belonged to a Swede.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: A board? What kind of board...?

dialogues.speaker: WANDERER
dialogues.text: A sun-shadow board. Here is one. Again he reaches into the thick pile of animal furs and t time produces a “solskuggerfol” board. It is a smallish wooden board with a pin or gnomon in the centre (which ca adjusted up or down) and with circles drawn around the pi WANDERER (CONT’D) To show you how it works, I need to float it in a tub of water. Ragnar goes off to fetch one. Once more the wanderer looks at his empty cup, and once m Lagertha re-fills it. And once more he empties the cup in one gulp. Outside the wind blasts against the house and makes the candles insid flutter and almost gutter. Ragnar returns with the tub of water and the wanderer pla the board in the water, where it floats. Then he takes a candle. WANDERER (CONT’D) This candle is the sun.  He holds the candle over the board. WANDERER (CONT’D) Each day the sun rises, and climbs in the sky until noon. (he arcs the candle across the board - the shadow shortens) See how the shadow shortens. At noon it will be at its shortest as the sun is at its zenith.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: But this only tells me how far south I have travelled -

dialogues.speaker: WANDERER
dialogues.text: Now listen. The day before you sail, mark a circle around the pointer on the board at the place where the shadow is shortest at noon. The next day at sea, place the board in water again around noon and watch for the shadow. If it only touches the circle, your course remains true. If the shadow passes outside the circle, like this, you have drifted and must steer further south. If the shadow never reaches the circle you are to the south and must steer more north. Keep the noon shadow on the circle and your course will be true. Ragnar and Lagertha stare at the board and the shadow as moves across it.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: Is it really true, wanderer, that you crossed the ocean using only this...this children’s toy?

dialogues.speaker: WANDERER
dialogues.text: Yes, I swear to you. I swear on my sacred ring. Of course, we also used ravens to show how far we might be from land, but the board took us across the open sea.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: I cannot believe it.  Ragnar looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: But if it’s true, Lagertha, just imagine! In just two days and nights we can reach the coast of England. We can find out for ourselves if what people have said is there really is there: rich lands, buildings made of stone, places filled with treasures. Don’t you want to go and find out? I do. A long beat. Lagertha looks at the board, then at the wanderer. Then she blows out the candle, plunging the board into darkness.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why did you do that?

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: Because there is something I want to know. I want to know what happens if there is no sun? How can the board help you then? How can you find your way.

dialogues.speaker: WANDERER
dialogues.text: You use this. He holds something out in his hand, but they can’t see wh it is. Ragnar brings another candle closer - and it shine upon a piece of semi-transluscent rock (actually a form o calcite).

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: WANDERER
dialogues.text: A sunstone.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: What good is it? The wanderer smiles.

dialogues.speaker: WANDERER
dialogues.text: I‘1l show you. Come outside. Ragnar leads them outside.  10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look up at the sky - even now, around noon, it’s a leaden grey, with no sign of the sun.

dialogues.speaker: WANDERER
dialogues.text: Watch. He holds up the sunstone. A beat. (The calcite works by polarizing light). The sunstone glows faintly, and an equally faint beam see to bounce back from it and illuminate a spot in the sky, behind the thick clouds. WANDERER (CONT’D) You see? There is the sun. It seems like a miracle. Neither Ragnar nor Lagertha can speak as they bear witness to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time has passed. Watched by her ten-year old daughter GYD Lagertha draws water from the well. Despite her reputatio a shield-maiden, Lagertha remains a slim, slight figure, long braided hair. It’s still cold enough for her breath to steam, but the i blasts of winter are over and the landscape breathes and greens. As she carries the bucket back towards the house we see various animals in timbered pens, for this is a working f And down by the water, a couple of small wooden boats. Two large and hairy hunting dogs shamble around the yard. Lagertha looks over at a neighboring property, where the HOUSEHOLDER is leaving, riding a small, wiry horse up the steep trail behind the houses. Glances back at her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: Gyda, feed the goats.  11. INT. RAGNAR’S HOUSE - DAY Lagertha, carrying the bucket inside, finds Ragnar puttin thick woollen coat over the shoulders of his son, BJORN, twelve years old, and a handsome, strong-looking youth. Lagertha stops and looks at them.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: What are you two doing?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: I’m taking Bjorn to the Thing.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: Not yet. He’s not old enough.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: He’s twelve years old.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: Take him next year. Next year is soon enough. Ragnar smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: He’1l need a silk ribbon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BJORN “spies” on his mother as Lagertha washes her long blonde hair in the tub of water. The water seems to flow slow motion from the ends of her hair like mercury as she kneels over the tub. His eyes are full of love for her.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: (quietly) Mother. Lagertha looks up, flicks back her hair so she can see hi and smiles tenderly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ragnar and Lagertha in bed together, cradled close after making. She stares into his eyes.  12.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: Don’t sleep with too many women in Kattegat.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Are you crazy? I won’t sleep with any of them. I don’t want to. I can do without it for a few weeks.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: Is that another way of saying you love me? She teases him.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: I always dream of you. Last night I dreamt you were feeding me blood pudding.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: It means you were giving me your heart. And they close in, and kiss passionately.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I love you so much I could feed you the whole sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father and son are ready to depart on their small, tough horses, both wearing heavy woollen coats, tight leather trousers, cloaks and leather boots. Lagertha and Gyda bring out some food for the journey, putting it into their saddle-bags. Bjorn kisses Gyda.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: Goodbye, little sister.

dialogues.speaker: GYDA
dialogues.text: Goodbye, big brother. Don’t get drunk.  13.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: Wait. I have something for both of you. She takes out two thin strips of colored ribbon, and ties around Bjorn’s head and the other around her husband's. LAGERTHA (CONT’D) There. Now everyone will know you are free men on your way to the Thing. Ragnar kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Goodbye my shield-maiden.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: Look after your son - and when you come back, just tell me the truth. I don’t care about anything else. And then she and her daughter watch Ragnar and Bjorn set up the rough trail towards the trees, accompanied by one the hunting dogs, Ragnar armed with a spear, a sword and knife and Bjorn with his hunting knife. Bjorn looks back once, and raises his arm in farewell, an then they are swallowed up into the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ride slowly on together through a landscape of fores scrub and rock. There is no-one else in sight, no farms o dwellings, for the rocky earth here is clearly unfit for agriculture or ploughing. Is even too barren for sheep. There are signs of spring everywhere, however, the trees brighter green, the gorse in flower.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: What will happen at the Thing?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Earl Haraldson will deal, as usual, with some criminal offences that have happened since the last meeting. And then everyone will discuss the summer raids.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: Where will you go?  14. There’s a long beat. Ragnar glances at his son, then away again, with a shrug.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: It’s not up to me. Earl Haraldson decides. I wish it was not so...but that is the law. But Bjorn can see that the question has affected his fath mood. They splash through a stream. RAGNAR (CONT’D) All the ice has gone. Spring is here again, thanks to Frey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have camped in the open. A fire is burning and they cooked some small animal over it and eaten it. The dog gn at the bones.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: There’s something I want to ask you.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Then ask me.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: How did you meet mother? Ragnar’s smiles.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Hasn’t she ever told you?

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: Of course. But I want to know if your story is the same as hers. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Well, it occurred when a Swedish chieftan invaded our part of Norway. I went off to fight him and many of the local women dressed up in men’s clothing and joined our camp. Lagertha was amongst them. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was impressed by her courage and courted her from afar.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: How far is that?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Hush. Listen. After a while I went to confess my love for her - but when I arrived I was set upon by a bear and an enormous hound who guarded her home. I killed the bear with my spear and managed to strangle the hound with my bare hands. (beat) And that’s the way I gained her hand in marriage. (glances at his son) What did she tell you? Bjorn smiles, then lies down, pulls the blanket over hims

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did she tell you the same story? A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: Just about. And he closes his eyes, still smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ride into Kattegat, a sizeable town and a trading station, set on the bank of a river. It’s a busy place wi open carts and covered wagons, horses and boats bringing people and goods to the local market, as well as delegate the Thing, wearing ribbons around their foreheads. At the market place, TRADERS - several of them of Arabic appearance, and dressed in totally different costumes - a examining the pelts, furs, ropes and bear-skins for sale. The ARABS are also examining the handful of SLAVES for sa most of Slavic appearance, checking their teeth, hair and nails, as if they were horses. There is a lot of good-humored banter and loud haggling. All of this Bjorn has clearly seen before, and is not faz by.  16. But then a large group of YOUNG MEN, clearly drunk, come swaggering through the market place, shouting out insults the traders and laughing, grabbing at the pelts and furs, creating a disturbance. The traders reclaim their goods and drive them away, angr Ragnar watches the incident with a heavy heart.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: Who are they?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Young men with nothing better to do. These days they regard the old ways, of trading and farming, as too tame. They think it’s stupid to acquire by sweat and toil what they can easily win by blood.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: Blood?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: In battle. (beat) It’s a real problem. There seem to be more and more of them every year. And it’s a great waste. Those young men are our future. Someone should harness their strength and their anger. They move on. Then a great bear of a man steps out before their horses, grabbing the bridles and laughing.

dialogues.speaker: BEAR MAN
dialogues.text: Ragnar Lothbrok! Ragnar and Bjorn dismount. Ragnar embraces him. BEAR MAN (CONT’D) Do my eyes deceive me? Is this your son? How he’s grown!

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Bjorn, this is your uncle Rollo. We sail in the same boat.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: Uncle. Rollo looks him up and down.  17.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLO
dialogues.text: So you’re here for the Thing? You’re a real man now. Let’s have a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long gloomy room, with a fire in the centre and benches arranged on either side. The men drink ale from horned cups. Rollo watches Bjorn s from his horn, and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLO
dialogues.text: You won’t get drunk like that. Bjorn smiles uneasily, then tips back the horn and drinks deeply. ROLLO (CONT’D) Are you ready for a woman? There are some good-looking women in Kattegat. And they’re free.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Of course he isn’t. He can’t even grow a beard. Rollo laughs again, empties his horn, and holds it out to refilled by a WOMAN with a jug. He stares at her wolfishl

dialogues.speaker: ROLLO
dialogues.text: So - where do you think he’1l send us this year?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Probably to the Eastlands again - the same as last year. The same as always.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLO
dialogues.text: Those bastards up there are as poor as we are. What do they have left to give us?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Only themselves. A beat. He glances round, lowers his voice.  18.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We should go west. I’ve heard such tales, Rollo. Great towns, cities and treasures; hordes of gold and silver. And a new god.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLO
dialogues.text: I’ve heard those stories too. But what does it mean? We can’t sail across an open ocean. A beat. Ragnar glances carefully at Bjorn, who has fallen asleep on his thigh. Lowers his voice again, despite the loud, drunken voices around him.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: We can. I believe there’s a way. Rollo looks at him. Then Ragnar picks up his son.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLO
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: To sleep.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLO
dialogues.text: I don’t understand you, Ragnar Lothbrok, everyone else comes here to get drunk in the company of good friends and to fuck beautiful women . Ragnar smiles.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: I’1l see you in the Great Hall. He carries his son away. INT. RAGNAR’S HOUSE - NIGHT Outside, a cold wind whips across the waters of the fjord Lagertha settles her daughter to sleep, telling her a sto

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: The giantess opened her rotting cavernous mouth and yawned. “Go away!” She said. “I want to sleep again. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not doing you any more favors.” She gave Freya a withering look. “My noble goddess,”she said, “you leap around at night like Heidrun cavorting with a herd of goats.” Gyda, warm beneath a bear skin, smiles sleepily. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: GYDA
dialogues.text: Go on!

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: Freya slowly raised her arms - like this! (raises her own arms) “I will girdle you with flame so you cannot leave this place without catching fire.” Hyndla laughed. “You’ve gone running to Od, who always loved you; and many another has wormed his way under your apron.” She pauses, checks the girl again...whose eyes are now closed. She is nearly asleep. LAGERTHA (CONT’D) (more quietly) There was fire in Asgard, dancing in the air. A band of flame, a quivering halo, surrounded the giantess. Her limbs tightened; she pressed her arms against her side.” Flames about me,” she cried. “The earth is on fire, and I must pay the full price or forfeit my life.” She stops, listens for a moment to the sound of her daughter’s easy breathing. Then leans down, kisses her forehead, and pulls the bear skin up to her neck. Lagertha moves through to the other chamber. The fire (in centre of the room) is dying down. But its flickering fla illuminate the war shields hung from hooks on the wall. S stares at them - and then unhooks one, and holds it to herself...as if remembering all the times she used it, in heat of battle. Now she stands proud with it, in the empty room, with onl the crackling of the logs and the moaning of the wind.  20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large and impressive chamber with a lattice of high bea and some wall coverings. It’s crowded. On a raised dais a one end, sat on a carved chair, is EARL HARALDSON, late forties and still a formidable-looking warrior, dressed i wide trousers and fur-trimmed coat. The Earl is flanked b some of his HOUSECARLS - his private, elite bodyguard - b SLAVES and several (mostly male) members of his FAMILY. H striking WIFE wears a sleeveless dress which reaches to t ground, and over it a sleeveless cape which is thrown bac revealing the whiteness of her arms. She is adorned with necklaces and oval brooches. Filling the rest of the hall, and obliged to stand, are FREEMEN like Ragnar and Rollo. In the small space between them a rather pathetic FIGURE standing, shifting from one foot to the other, his eyes downcast. He’s almost a figure of fun and everyone is grinning at him.

dialogues.speaker: EARL HARALDSON
dialogues.text: Olaf Anwend...

dialogues.speaker: OLAF
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: EARL HARALDSON
dialogues.text: You have pleaded guilty to the charge of stealing. Tomorrow you will run a gauntlet of stones and turf as punishment.

dialogues.speaker: OLAF
dialogues.text: Yes, lord. Thank you, lord.

dialogues.speaker: EARL HARALDSON
dialogues.text: Don’t thank me. And let it be known that a fine is to be paid by anyone who fails to throw something. There’s laughter - as Olaf is led away. Bjorn tries his b to peer through the men blocking his view of events.

dialogues.speaker: EARL HARALDSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bring in the next accused. Bjorn actually catches a glimpse of the YOUNG MAN brought into the hall in chains by the housecarls. The young man a pleasant expression, keeps his head high and does not a his eyes.  21.

dialogues.speaker: EARL HARALDSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Eric Trygvasson, you are accused of the murder of Sigvald Strut this January. How do you plead?

dialogues.speaker: TRYGVASSON
dialogues.text: It wasn’t murder, lord. I killed him in self-defence. It was he who attacked me.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: LIAR
dialogues.text: The WOMAN is part of the dead man’s family, standing in a group close to the defendant.

dialogues.speaker: EARL HARALDSON
dialogues.text: If it wasn’t murder, why did you not declare your crime to the first person you met afterwards, as the law obliges? In fact, you passed by several houses before you reported it. Trygvasson looks over at the woman and the dead man’s fam

dialogues.speaker: TRYGVASSON
dialogues.text: I...I thought the relatives of the dead man might be living in them.

dialogues.speaker: EARL HARALDSON
dialogues.text: The law allows you to pass two houses in such circumstances - but never a third.

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY MEMBER
dialogues.text: You felt guilty. You went to his house and murdered my brother in cold blood. Fresh uproar. Bjorn struggles to keep an eye-line on the accused. Ragnar notices, lifts him up.

dialogues.speaker: TRYGVASSON
dialogues.text: It’s not true. We argued about some land. He pulled out a knife...

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: You’re lying! You wanted that land for yourself. You're a liar and a coward.  22.

dialogues.speaker: TRYGVASSON
dialogues.text: Who says I’m a coward? I’m no coward. More people join in the shouting. The Earl bangs his fist the table.

dialogues.speaker: EARL HARALDSON
dialogues.text: Silence! All of you - show some respect. They fall silent. Earl Haraldson looks at Trygvasson.

dialogues.speaker: EARL HARALDSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As the normal procedures were not followed, this killing cannot be atoned for by compensating the victim’s family. The family shout their approval, raise their fists aggressively towards the defendant.

dialogues.speaker: EARL HARALDSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Murder is a dishonorable act among our people, Eric Trygvasson, committed in secret, unacknowledged and very likely to set in train a cycle of revenge killings, which would also involve your own family. He looks up at the assembly.

dialogues.speaker: EARL HARALDSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I ask all of you how you find the accused. If you think him guilty, raise your arms. Your decision must be unanimous. Quickly, everyone raises their hands. But the Earl hesita for someone has not. Ragnar realizes who it is and squeez Bjorn’s thigh. Bjorn raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: EARL HARALDSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Eric Trygvasson, you have been found guilty of murder. How would you like to die? A beat. Trygvasson looks round the room in that same cool way, as if he was above it all.

dialogues.speaker: TRYGVASSON
dialogues.text: By beheading, lord.  23.

dialogues.speaker: EARL HARALDSON
dialogues.text: Granted. Your execution will take place tomorrow. And afterwards we shall feast and discuss the summer raids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To jeers and shouts, Olaf Anwend runs the gauntlet of sto and turf. He staggers down the line of people, women as w as men, throwing the missiles at him. Bjorn watches with Ragnar, at first enjoying the comic aspects of the scene - then wincing slightly as Olaf is struck by stone after stone, staggers, and starts to blee Ragnar offers the boy a stone. Bjorn looks uncertain.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: You have to. A beat. Ragnar turns and throws the stone himself at Anwe hitting his leg. Anwend struggles on, everyone still enjo the comedic aspects. With a laugh Rollo throws a large ro at Anwend, which hits his head and makes him cry out with pain. Bjorn grabs a handful of turf and throws it, missing easi and deliberately. Bleeding heavily, but alive, Anwend crawls the last few y to the end of the line, where with renewed hilarity a buc of cold water is poured over his bleeding head, and he emerges - grinning like a madman. Then Earl Haraldson and his entourage appear, the houseca bringing Eric Trygvasson to his execution. Trygvasson’s hands, unlike at the trial, are now unbound, and he walks resolutely up to the wooden block on which he will be decapitated. He smiles at the crowds gathered around him, and acknowle the dead man’s family.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: Why is he smiling, father?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: He wants to die well, of course, without fear. To atone for his sins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bjorn looks puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLO
dialogues.text: Cattle die, kinsfolk die, we ourselves must die. But one thing I know will never die - a dead man’s reputation. Remember that, young Bjorn. Trygvasson kneels on the grass and puts his head on the stone. A HOUSECARL with an axe approaches, first lays the blade of the axe flat on his head, then presents the blad for him to kiss. Trygvasson kisses the blade eagerly, and almost tenderly. Bjorn turns his head away.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: You must watch - for his sake. This is his only hope of reaching Valhalla. Bjorn forces himself to watch. The axe falls, striking off Trygvasson’s head, which roll away into the grass. Earl Haraldson picks up the head and contemptuously tosse to the dead man’s family.

dialogues.speaker: EARL HARALDSON
dialogues.text: Here. Feed it to your pigs. I curse him. May he never enter Valhalla. Ragnar looks shocked. He’s not the only one.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: Why did he do that?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: I don’t know. He should not have done. Not according to our law. He must have wanted that land himself. And he exchanges a meaningful glance with Rollo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The oars of a small boat slice cleanly into the waters of fyord. Bjorn stares down silently into the water, but the reflections on its surface make it seem like the mountain are in the water.  25. Ragnar rows, keeping close to the shore, beneath the lee the overhanging cliffs and slopes of scree which fall she to the fyord. Bjorn drops a smooth round pebble into the water and watc it drop and drop, deeper and deeper into the clear depths Bjorn watches his father row.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: Now where are we going, father?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: To visit a friend.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: A friend? What’s his name?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: His name is Floki. Bjorn stares at the high, snow-capped hills, the great, almost overwhelming beauty of it.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: Like Loki, the god?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Yes, like Loki. Only... different.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: How is he different?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Well... (thinks) He’s not a god. Bjorn laughs.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: Why didn’t he come to the Thing? A long beat. Oars slice through the deep still waters. On could well imagine that the gods were here, among these unnaturally beautiful, silent places.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Because he’s...because he’s shy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They’ve pulled the boat onto a narrow beach in a hidden b There’s no sign of habitation. They walk up a steep path through the trees. When a FIGURE leaps out at them, wearing a fierce mask, a with a hideous screech. Bjorn is shocked...but still calm enough to draw out his hunting knife. Ragnar laughs.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: It’s all right. Put your knife away. (beat) Floki, meet my son. Bjorn...this is my dear friend Floki. FLOKI rips off his mask, and grins. He has a strange, mischievous, almost ageless face, ugly but animated, with bright, piercing eyes.

dialogues.speaker: FLOKI
dialogues.text: Hello. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: Well, thank you...sir. Floki stares at his face.

dialogues.speaker: FLOKI
dialogues.text: Let me see. You have your father’s eyes - unfortunately.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Why unfortunately?

dialogues.speaker: FLOKI
dialogues.text: It means he will be like you. And therefore he will want to do better than you. And you will hate him for it.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: He’s only twelve years old.  27.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: How can you tell that by just looking at my face?

dialogues.speaker: FLOKI
dialogues.text: It’s the same with trees.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: With trees?

dialogues.speaker: FLOKI
dialogues.text: Yes. I can tell which trees will make the best planks just by looking at them. I can look inside the tree.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Floki is a boat-builder. Bjorn stares around at the deeply-forested hill they are

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: So - you could tell which of these trees would make the best planks for a ship? Floki grins...then abruptly walks off the path, and into trees. They follow him. For their POV - and from ours - all the trees look the sa virtually identical. But Floki stares at them with a strange, bewitching intensity....touching the trunks of some of them, laying cheek against the bark, staring up at the uppermost branc Whatever amusement Bjorn might derive from seeing a man staring at trees is quickly confounded by the aura of spiritual intensity which surrounds Floki. He’s no ordina mortal. It’s not possible to laugh at the way he examines bark of tress, or caresses them, or simply just looks at them. Floki is different. Strange but compelling. Authentic.

dialogues.speaker: FLOKI
dialogues.text: (suddenly) This is one. He indicates a tree - to the others, just like the rest o the trees...and yet. Floki strokes the trunk.  28. FLOKI (CONT’D) Inside this tree are two almost perfect planks. They will bend, then curve, like a woman’s body, from the thigh to the back. When I split the tree I will find them. He marks the tree with a couple of blows from his axe. Bjorn laughs.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: You can see that?

dialogues.speaker: FLOKI
dialogues.text: Do you think I’m joking? I joke about many things, son of Ragnar, but never about ship-building. Our boats are our souls. Bjorn looks abashed - embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: So - how is our boat? Floki looks back at him. And grins.

dialogues.speaker: FLOKI
dialogues.text: Ah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A secret, turf-covered shed close by the edge of the wate Gloomy - but slightly “religious” in the way the space is by tallow candles. Watched by Ragnar and Bjorn, Floki uncovers the skeleton a new boat. It’s still in a rudimentary shape, its spars naked. Even so, Ragnar is immediately entranced.

dialogues.speaker: FLOKI
dialogues.text: What do you think, Ragnar Lothrok?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: It’s bigger! The hull’s deeper.  29.

dialogues.speaker: FLOKI
dialogues.text: Yes, but it will be lighter and faster than before, and carry a much bigger sail. The construction is different. It’s built with a strong central plank. The two strakes above it are nailed directly onto the knees of the frames. But the ones below - look! - are cleated and lashed onto the frames, not nailed, so they can move in relation to each other. This means the boat will not butt against the waves like a goat, but move over them like a ripple. Ragnar continues to study the boat. Meanwhile, Bjorn studies Floki’s tools with all the fascination they exert upon a young boy’s mind. Planes, s shaped bores, small axes and rivets. And then, almost wit shock, he sees the small, strange figure hunched in the shadows, wearing a conical hat and grinning. It’s a woode statue of the god Loki and the grin is not pleasant, but wicked and somehow disturbing. Bjorn moves quickly away.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Why have you cut the oarports into the sheerstrake?

dialogues.speaker: FLOKI
dialogues.text: It makes it easier to row, and the ports can be closed when the boat is at sea.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: You think this boat could handle long sea voyages?

dialogues.speaker: FLOKI
dialogues.text: That’s why I built it.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: And it will be strong enough? Floki shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: FLOKI
dialogues.text: We won’t know that until we try. Ragnar looks at him.  30.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: When will it be ready?

dialogues.speaker: FLOKI
dialogues.text: Ah, as to that...

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FLOKI
dialogues.text: We’re out of money. We have to pay for the sail...and then the anchor. You know what those blacksmiths are like! Such greedy bastards. A beat. Ragnar reluctantly brings out a leather pouch.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: This is almost all I have left from last summer’s raids. Floki takes the pouch, with a grin.

dialogues.speaker: FLOKI
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, Ragnar Lothbrok. We’1l soon be as rich as dwarves! And he laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great trestles have been set up and the freemen sit aroun them, drinking and ready to feast. Music is playing. Earl Haraldson, with his wife and family members, sits at high table. There is much laughter in the hall. Then a horn is sounde for silence.

dialogues.speaker: EARL HARALDSON
dialogues.text: Before we feast, we have an important ceremony to perform. Two young men have joined us for the first time and must receive their arm-rings. Olaf the son of Ingolf and Bjorn son of Ragnar Lothbrok. Both of you come up here. Bjorn and the other YOUNG MAN approach the high table. Th Earl walks round to the front of the dais...and draws his sword.  31.

dialogues.speaker: EARL HARALDSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Kneel. They both kneel. A housecarl slips two ornate bracelets o twisted silver, the clasps fashioned as animal heads, ont the blade. Earl Haraldson holds the blade close to the yo men’s faces.

dialogues.speaker: EARL HARALDSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These rings symbolize your coming of age - and they also bind you in loyalty to me, your chieftan. Any oath you swear upon your ring, you must honor and keep, or else lose your honor. Do you understand and do you swear so?

dialogues.speaker: BOYS
dialogues.text: Yes, lord.

dialogues.speaker: EARL HARALDSON
dialogues.text: And you freely recognize your fealty to me?

dialogues.speaker: BOYS
dialogues.text: Yes, lord.

dialogues.speaker: EARL HARALDSON
dialogues.text: Then take your rings. The boys take their rings from the point of the sword and clasp them around their arms. Ragnar looks on proudly. Th sees that Haraldson is staring at him. But the moment is lost as the freemen shout out their approval, banging their fists on the tables as the boys return, embarrassed but delighted, to their seats.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Let me look! Ah - it’s a fine ring. Never lose it, my son, or something dreadful will happen to you.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: I won't father.

dialogues.speaker: EARL HARALDSON
dialogues.text: Now let’s feast. Ragnar suddenly stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lord...we all want to feast: but we also want to know where we will be raiding this summer.

dialogues.speaker: EARL HARALDSON
dialogues.text: Can’t it wait?

dialogues.speaker: ROLLO
dialogues.text: No, tell us. We’re anxious to know. We have a right to know. A beat. The hall has fallen silent.

dialogues.speaker: EARL HARALDSON
dialogues.text: Very well. Then we shall go raiding to the east again, into the Eastlands, into Rus...

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Every year we do the same thing. We raid people who have nothing more than we have. We have a hard life, and they have a hard life - but we take from them even the few things which they have. But, lord, we have an alternative...a choice...another journey... 32. There is a groundswell of noise...of some disagreement. T Earl is alive to it.

dialogues.speaker: EARL HARALDSON
dialogues.text: Oh yes, I too have heard the rumors. I hear that if we sail west, across the open, fathomless ocean, we shall somehow come to lands far richer and more plentiful. Yes, I have heard those stories. But I tell you now that I will not risk my ships or my reputation on wild, speculative and unrealistic visions. (beat) I pay for the ships. Therefore they go where I tell them to go, and that is the end of the matter. (beat) Now let’s feast. He claps his hands...and the feast is brought in. Ragnar looks at Rollo, who shrugs.  33. Then a HOUSECARL approaches their table. The housecarl ha livid scar which runs from the corner of his mouth up his cheek to his eye.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSECARL
dialogues.text: Ragnar Lothbrok, Earl Haraldson wants to speak with you in private. Ragnar nods, glances reassuringly at Bjorn, follows the housecarl behind the dais, into a small chamber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haraldson is flanked by several of his heavily-armed HOUSECARLS. It’s an intimidating atmosphere.

dialogues.speaker: EARL HARALDSON
dialogues.text: Ragnar Lothbrok...

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Yes, lord.

dialogues.speaker: EARL HARALDSON
dialogues.text: Are you hungry? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Yes, lord.

dialogues.speaker: EARL HARALDSON
dialogues.text: You want to feast in my hall? You want to sail in my ship? What else do you want of me?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Lord, I - Haraldson slams his fist onto the table. The housecarls c around him.

dialogues.speaker: EARL HARALDSON
dialogues.text: I know you question my rule. I know you have big ideas. But you should keep them to yourself, Ragnar Lothbrok. What are you? You’re a farmer. Remember that. You’re just a lowly farmer. And you owe obedience and rent to me. (beat) I warn you. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: EARL HARALDSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you dare to stick your nose in my face, I will kill you. He stares at Ragnar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ragnar leads his sleepy son by the hand through the dark settlement. Bjorn trips over something, yowls. Dogs bark.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: Where are we going now?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Just to a place. Just to see someone.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: What place? To see who? (beat) I’m so tired. Ragnar sees a lamp set outside a low door.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Here it is. Wake up. He finds the door open, pushes his son inside, follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few low tallow candles, otherwise darkness. The shapes things. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: I’m frightened. Ragnar grasps his wrist. Then there’s the sound of a voic ancient, unsexed.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Why don’t you come in? I’m waiting. Ragnar encourages his son to push aside the curtained wal and go inside.  35. The ANCIENT SEER is sitting in the dark. An old man or wo with withered dugs, sightless, white-eyed. Probably an ol woman, it’s actually impossible to tell. But there’s a strange and powerful aura about the figure which makes Bj instinctively recoil. Before her is a bowl of dried brown shrivelled mushrooms. She reaches out gnarled fingers and chews one.

dialogues.speaker: ANCIENT WOMAN
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: I want to know what the gods have in store.

dialogues.speaker: ANCIENT WOMAN
dialogues.text: For you - or for your son?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: I’m more interested in myself. The ancient hag chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: ANCIENT WOMAN
dialogues.text: The gods desire you to have a great future. I see that. But they can withdraw their goodwill at any time.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: To have this great future, must I challenge the law? This seems to be the nub of it. There’s a pause. The anci one reaches out and touches his face and her sightless ey peer into his.

dialogues.speaker: ANCIENT WOMAN
dialogues.text: It is always possible for a man to shape his own fate. You must convince the gods to alter the runes, so they work in your favor. But the laws of men are far below the workings and shapings of the gods.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: So I should take the law of men into my own hands? Silence.  36.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You won’t answer me!

dialogues.speaker: ANCIENT WOMAN
dialogues.text: You already have your answer.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: No I don’t. I don’t have the real answer.

dialogues.speaker: ANCIENT WOMAN
dialogues.text: Then go and ask the gods themselves. What are you afraid of? Looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: (quietly) Who is not afraid of the gods? The old hag grins. Looks sightlessly at Bjorn.

dialogues.speaker: ANCIENT WOMAN
dialogues.text: I say only this to you: beware of your sons.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: My sons? I have only one son.

dialogues.speaker: ANCIENT WOMAN
dialogues.text: I see more.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Why should I beware of them? The ancient stares at Ragnar again with her white, blind - and will not answer. Turns instead and stares, sightles at Bjorn, who is afraid of her, looks away.

dialogues.speaker: ANCIENT WOMAN
dialogues.text: Look at me, child. Bjorn steels himself to look back at her. After a few moments, she nods. ANCIENT WOMAN (CONT’D) I think your son is ready. Take him up to the temple. Let him also see the gods and, if he wishes, speak to them. That’s all I can tell you.  37.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: You haven't helped me at all, old woman . A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: ANCIENT WOMAN
dialogues.text: Perhaps you asked the wrong questions. In any case, sometimes you should not try to forsee your fate, for it is best not to know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ragnar and Bjorn ride their small horses inland, up the s of the mountain. It’s a hard trek. The landscape is harsh dramatic with huge rock formations and boulders scattered across it.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: This looks like a place where the giants might live. Ragnar smiles.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: You know very well that the giants dwell in Utgard, in the outer place. And between Midgard, where we live, and Utgard there is a great sea.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: Not our sea?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: A bigger sea than that. And the Midgard serpent encircles it and holds the sea in.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: Don’t the giants ever come here, into our world?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: They try to. They are shapeshifters. They can appear disguised as anything. But the gods look after us. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They are forever watching out, in case the giants try to cross the sea and bring their chaos with them.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: And the dwarves help too?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Yes, you can’t always trust them of course - but they are a help to the gods sometimes. They bind Fenrir the wolf, so he can’t escape and swallow the sun.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: If Fennir is so big and strong, how do they bind him...?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: With things you can’t see or hear: like the breath of a fish; the sound a cat makes when it’s walking, and the roots of a mountain. Bjorn nods, satisfied with the explanation. Takes it in.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: I’m hungry.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Then we must catch something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand up to their knees in the cold flowing waters, with spears raised. They wait, and wait...and then both plunge their spears i the water. Bjorn extracts a fish on the point of his spear, still flapping. He grins. EXT. RAGNAR’S FARM - DAY Lagertha is milking the goats in the milking shed. One of goat’s is giving her trouble. She tries to coax it gently Then Gyda comes rushing in, looking frightened.  39.

dialogues.speaker: GYDA
dialogues.text: Mother. She glances over her shoulder. Lagertha understands that something is wrong.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: (to Gyda) Stay here. She walks outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two YOUNG MEN - just like the young men who rain riot thr the town, are standing arrogantly in the yard. They are armed.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: FIRST YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Where’s your husband, woman?

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: He’s at the Thing - where you should be. You’re old enough.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Don’t taunt us, woman. We know you're alone here. All the men are gone.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: If you’re thirsty I will give you a drink. If you’re hungry I will feed you. Otherwise you must go.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: We’ll eat and drink after we've satisfied our other needs. Let’s go into your house. By way of a threat, he touches the axe head in his belt. A beat. Then Lagertha nods.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: All right. (looks over her shoulder) Stay in the shed, Gyda. Do as I say.  40. She leads the way into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young men feel frisky, cocky. They laugh, nudge each other.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Where’s your softest bed? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: In here. She leads them into the shield room. Springing forward, s snatches a shield from the wall. They take the axes from their belts.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: We don’t want to kill you, woman.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: You couldn't kill me if you tried for a hundred years. She swoops into a secret place, and pulls out a sword. Now she is a shield-maiden again. Her eyes have hardened. is changed. For the first time, the two young men are not so sure.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Before you try anything, think about your daughter.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: I am thinking about my daughter. Now you will leave my house or I will gut you like fish and cook your entrails. She attacks them with frightening speed. No sooner has th first young man raised his axe than she has sheared off t handle with her blade. She slashes at the second young ma once, ripping his clothes open, and a second time slashin the side of his face. He screams. His blood splashes on the floor.  41. Lagertha fixes her attentions on the first, now unarmed y man...who loses his nerve and bolts for it. His companion bleeding copiously, bolts after him. Lagertha takes a moment to compose herself - then hurries outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gyda is hiding among the goats. Lagertha takes her into h arms.

dialogues.speaker: GYDA
dialogues.text: Have they gone?

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: Yes, they've gone.

dialogues.speaker: GYDA
dialogues.text: What did they want?

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: They were travellers. They were thirsty, that’s all. (beat) Shall we go on milking the goats?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ride up, through the thinning line of trees, to the of the plain. And stop. A majestic but also strange sight greets them. In the distance is the golden dome of the temple. It’s surrounde three sides by a grove of trees which are remarkable, eve this distance, because there are very few other trees on high plateau. But dotted around there are some large earth mounds, clea man-made; burial mounds, but now covered in grass. And al huge piles of stones. Bjorn knows what they are and doesn have to ask. The whole vista is strange, haunting.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: There it is.  42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ride towards the temple, between the trees. There’s strange atmosphere here. Hidden bells chime very softly, sweetly like a sighing wind.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Keep to the path. The grove is sacred. Every nine years, here in the temple, the priests sacrifice nine of everything and hang them in the trees.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: Nine of everything? Nine sheep and nine hens?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: And nine horses?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Of course. We love our horses. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: And nine of us? Nine humans? Ragnar looks back at his son, but doesn’t answer. Now Bjorn becomes aware of waif-like creatures flitting between the trees, dressed in pale colored robes. BJORN (CONT’D) Father, who are they?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Priests, I expect. Or other things. Who can tell in a place like this? Look, here’s the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They dismount in front of two large wooden doors, studded with iron. A PRIEST appears, bows, silently opens the doors. He is a tall, thin, homosexual YOUNG MAN, dressed in a flowing ro  43. And they step inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The golden glow from the roof generates a strange, almost unearthly light. There’s a water-source somewhere...for t sound of water running and splashing fills the great dome space. The space is dominated by three huge wooden statues, seve metres high, made of highly polished wood. But the priest first takes them over to the stone altar on which there i sacred Viking ring, a wooden bowl filled with blood and a twig. Ragnar kneels by the altar and Bjorn follows his example. priest dips the twig into the blood of a sacrificed anima and shakes it over them, sprinkling them with blood.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: (sing-song) Hail to the Aesir! Hail to the goddesses! Hail to the mighty, fecund earth. Wit and wisdom may you give us, and healing hands while we live! They move towards the statues, Ragnar once more sinking t his knees and making his obeisance. Bjorn looks confused and over-awed. But the priest, with smile, gently guides him closer.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My son, you have travelled a long way, but now at last you are face to face with our gods. He draws Bjorn gently towards the first statue: of a mass muscle-bound, bearded, earthy-looking figure holding alof his mighty hammer. PRIEST (CONT’D) This is Thor. You know him, of course. You hear him in the thunder, when he races across the clouds with his goats. He protects all of us. And when he goes forth with his hammer, Mjollni, in his hand, he is irresistible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Thor’s sculpted face, his exaggerated features, peasant-like, wide-mouth, bulbous nose - rather comic-boo The priest draws Bjorn towards the second statue: a figur with a disproportionately huge and erect phallus.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know who this is?

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: (tentative) Frey?

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Of course it’s Frey. Who else could it be? The god of sunshine and rain, of fertility, of children and crops. Of harvests. Of everything that grows new...but is cut down again each year. Then grows once more. (beat) Come. He draws Bjorn to the last figure. We have seen this figu before: a tall, thin figure holding a spear, wearing a cl and a wide-brimmed hat, under which his single eye peeps Even carved in wood, there is something magnetic but also something sinister, even terrifying about the image.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And this...

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: ++.is Odin.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Odin. god of war, of warriors slain in battle. He lives in his great hall at Valhalla, with all the reborn warriors, feasting and drinking... Ragnar suddenly cuts in.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Odin is not only the god of those slain in battle. He is many other things. He is our universal father. He is the god of Skalds; he governs the mystic ecstacy, the great pathos, the passion of the soul. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He is the god of thought..of curiosity. He wanted to look into the well of knowledge, guarded by the wise, decapitated Mimi. They told him he would have to lose an eye to gain knowledge...and gladly he did it. You see there, Bjorn? He has but one eye. But with that single-eye he sees everything. A beat. He takes out two small coins, gives them to the priest.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you for your time, priest. The priest is clearly offended, and would like to say something stinging - but manages to restrain himself. He bows, walks out. A long beat. Bjorn is still staring up at the statue of O as if mesmerized. RAGNAR (CONT’D) (softly) Bjorn...there’s something you should know. Our family are direct descendants of Odin. Odin was once aman. He fought and made a great name for himself, and when he died he became a god. But he was once a man, with a family and a home. And it is written in the runes that we are directly descended from his family.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: We are descended from gods? No father. How can it be?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: It is so. Which is why I believe I have inherited the god’s curiosity. He loved knowledge. He wanted to find out about things. And so do I. I want to find out what lies to the west of us...what cities and gods are over there. I’m not satisfied with staying here, in this small country, where everyone has to scratch out a living, unless you're an earl. Odin gave his eye to acquire knowledge, but I would give far more.  46. Bjorn stares up again at the giant statue of the one-eyed god.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go outside and wait for me. Bjorn nods, and leaves Ragnar alone with his god. RAGNAR (CONT’D) (quietly) Lord, O High One, I have sworn my life to you, and I have come to ask your advice. Is it not true that, in the beginning of everything, you led the revolt of the Aesir against the Vanir? Was it not you, Lord, who burned the body of the witch Gullveig three times? And did you not sit in your high seat in Valhalla sharpening your spear and polishing your shield? And when the gods moved against each other, was it not you who cast the first spear into the host of the Vanir? (beat) So I have come to ask, have I your permission to rise in revolt against my earthly lord? Would you give me your blessing, if I cast the first spear? Lord, O High One, if you would forgive or encourage me, I ask only that you give me a sign. Odin stares back at him with his single eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ragnar and Lagertha sit on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: How was it?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Good. Earl Haraldson gave Bjorn his arm-ring. Then I took him up to the temple.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: So many things at once. My poor son.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: He didn’t complain. Then I took him to see the new boat.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: How is it?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: We won’t know until we sail in her, but she looks good. He reaches out, touches her cheek. RAGNAR (CONT’D) I missed you. Did anything happen while we were away?

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Did you miss me?

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: I was too busy on the farm to miss you.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Is that true? She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: No. I ached with love longing. My belly was empty of laughter.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: How can I make you laugh now?

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: I don’t want to laugh now. She pushes him back on the bed, and gets astride him. LAGERTHA (CONT’D) I want to ride you, like a bull. Like a wild bull.  48. She rocks back and forth, her eyes gleaming. Unclasps her hair and leans down to kiss him, her hair falling all aro him. LAGERTHA (CONT’D) Now bull, now. He starts to make love to her. In the other room, by the smouldering fire, Bjorn can hea them. His parents make love loudly, shouting, and the bed shakes. Untroubled, he saunters outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are struck, again, by the immense, almost overwhelming beauty of this place. A beauty that seems almost unreal. A small boat is approaching, cutting through the calm wat dwarfed by the distant mountains. It reaches the naroow shingle beach and Rollo climbs out, fastens it to a post.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: Hello Rollo. Rollo ruffles the boy’s hair.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLO
dialogues.text: Hello, young Bjorn. ROLLO (CONT’D) Where are your parents? Bjorn is matter of fact.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: They’re fucking. Rollo laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ragnar, Lagertha, Bjorn, Gyda and Rollo eat and drink. Ro drinks copiously. Looks at Gyda.  49.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLO
dialogues.text: So, Gyda, tell me: is your mother teaching you how to use a shield?

dialogues.speaker: GYDA
dialogues.text: Yes. I know how to use a shield. I know what it’s for.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLO
dialogues.text: Your mother was a famous shield- maiden.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: Not so much of the “was” please, Rollo. “Is” will do.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLO
dialogues.text: Is...a famous shield-maiden. We fought in the same shieldwall. Against the Eastlanders. She fought like a Valkyrie.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: I fought to protect my husband, my brothers and my father. They, too, were in the shieldwall. I would have died, willingly, for any of them. Ragnar looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: You nearly did. (It’s something between them) She rises.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: Come on children, to bed. We’1l leave the men.

dialogues.speaker: BJORN
dialogues.text: I’m aman. I have a ring.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: To bed!

dialogues.speaker: BJORN AND GYDA
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Good night, my children.  50. Kisses them. They go off. Ragnar pours more mead for them both.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLO
dialogues.text: Tell me your news: what about the boat?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: I’ve seen it. It’s a wonderful thing, Rollo. It’s almost half- finished.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLO
dialogues.text: Do you trust Floki? Isn’t he a great joker?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: He’s a great boat builder. I trust him to do that.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLO
dialogues.text: And the sun board and the sunstone - you believe they can guide you across the sea?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: I do. (beat) But I have to ask you this: when the boat is finished, will you sail west with me? There’s a long beat. Rollo drinks, wipes his mouth. Stare him.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLO
dialogues.text: Only if we're all equal. I won’t go under your command. Ragnar slips the ring from his arm. Holds it out to Rollo

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: I swear on my sacred ring, I swear before Odin, that everyone in the boat will be equal, and will share equally what we find. (beat) Will you come? A beat. Then Rollo reaches out, and also takes hold of th ring.  51.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLO
dialogues.text: I will come. I swear. Ragnar grins, embraces him. But Rollo is still staring at him. ROLLO (CONT’D) But we must find a crew. Not many men will go against the wishes of Earl Haraldson. Many of them will be afraid, and if we approach them some may even go to him and betray us.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Leave that to me. I have a good idea where we will find our crew. Rollo looks at him quizzically, but doesn’t question him.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLO
dialogues.text: You're very determined, Ragnar Lothbrok. How do you know we'll be successful?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: I don’t know. But what I do know is that our fates are already decided. One way or another, we can’t change them. A beat. Then Lagertha comes back in.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: They’re asleep. She sits down. Ragnar rises.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: I must go and piss. He walks outside. Rollo pours Lagertha some mead.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: Thank you. She smiles at him. He tries to hold her gaze.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLO
dialogues.text: I’ve always wanted you. Always.  52.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: That’s too bad. She smiles again, but he takes it like an insult - reache out and grabs her wrist. She spills her drink.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLO
dialogues.text: Don’t insult me, shield-maiden. Looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: No. I would never insult you. You're too great a warrior. Eyes tight on each other. Then he releases his grip. LAGERTHA (CONT’D) But not so great a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ragnar finishes his piss. The landscape is bathed in moonlight, which gives everything a mysterious look. Ragn gaze is somehow drawn across to the edge of the woods...a wolf emerges. The wolf walks down the meadow a little way, completely unafraid. Then stops, and seems to look back at Ragnar fo few long moments. And then it turns, moves away among the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ragnar comes back in. Is immediately aware that something happened between Lagertha and Rollo - but chooses to igno it. He sits down again.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: I saw a wolf in the meadow.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLO
dialogues.text: You must kill it. Ragnar looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: No. I mustn’t kill it.  53.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLO
dialogues.text: Why not? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Because it wasn’t a wolf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bjorn lies in his narrow bed, still awake. He can hear the adult conversations in the next room. His hand still grips the arm-ring he’s been given, for he wil never let it go. When he closes his eyes he sees the statue of Odin. Odin staring at him with his one eye. But the eye is alive. An his gaze is terrible. It bores into you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are in the fjord. Clouds scud across the sky. The mountains soar into the blue air, and fall into the water below. The water is full of reflections - of the sky, of the forests. A waterfall cascades down the side of a mountain, foaming over the rocks, sending up a fine mist of spray. This is nature, raw and elemental. We hear Lagertha’s voice. LAGERTHA V.O. A pyre was built around the body of Balder and his wife Nana, dry faggots that needed nothing more than a spark to leap into their own life and consume the lifeless bodies that lay upon them, releasing their bodies to travel on.  54. INT. RAGNAR’S HOUSE - EVENING Lagertha recites the saga to her children, who listen, li frozen things listening.

dialogues.speaker: LAGERTHA
dialogues.text: Balder’s horse, meanwhile, was galloping along the foreshore and worked into a streaming sweat. Then a servant plunged a short dagger into its throat. It gave a violent jerk and, without a sound, crumpled among the wrack..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ragnar is out fishing with his son, Bjorn, in the deep soundless waters of the fjord. RAGNAR V.O. Now Odin strode through the shallows and gripped the gunwale. He climbed into the boat and stood over the body of his dead son. For some time he gazed at him... Ragnar gazes at the very alive, very animated face of his son. Then he speaks aloud:

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Then Odin bent down and put his mouth to Balder’s ear. Again he gazed at his son; then he left the boat. Ragnar looks over at the shore, and points out something his son. Someone has kindled a fire on the far shore. LAGERTHA V.O. At a sign from Odin a servant stepped forward with a lighted brand. He set fire to the pyre and at once a steady plume of smoke, twisting and spiralling, rose into the calm air. And as father and son stare at the sight on the far shore this is exactly what they see.  55. A boat has been set on fire - and the smoke, twisting and spiralling, rises into the calm air. INT. RAGNAR’S HOUSE - EVENING Ragnar goes on with the nighttime saga, as the children h between wake and sleep.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Thor raised his hammer. Slowly and solemnly he intoned the magic words to hallow the cremation. Then a dwarf called Lit came running along the water’s edge. He passed right in front of Thor, and Thor was so enraged that he put out a foot and tripped him. The dwarf flew threw the air and landed right on the licking and curdling pyre. In this way, he was burned to death beside Balder. Bjorn bursts out laughing at the thought of the dwarf fly into the fire. He laughs and laughs. And Ragnar smiles, a even his daughter is tickled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father and son watch the boat, now completely alight, dri slowly across the water. It’s a fantastic, compelling ima the fire reflected in the water so it seems to spread out right across the fjord. RAGNAR V.O. The boat drifted across the water. Sea winds caught at her and tugged her away. First she was more boat than flame, but soon more flame than boat. She was a quivering shape, a farewell on the horizon, moving on under a great cloud of her own making. And so it is. And the boat burns on. INT. RAGNAR’S HOUSE - DAWN The first brightness in the night sky. A little rill of light.  56. The moon is still in the sky, pale and diminishing. The camera travels through the house and its sleeping inhabitants. We see the colored shields, some weapons. Th ashes of a fire, a slaughtered beast upon a hook. The children asleep, like any other children. But Bjorn s clasping his arm-ring in a deathless grip. The small stat of Freya. A sleeping cat. Ragnar and Lagertha naked and asleep, coiled together. Then Ragnar opens his eyes. And the first thing he sees is a horrifying mask. And the hears laughter, and Floki rips off the mask as he stands their bed. Ragnar stares up at him, covering his cock.

dialogues.speaker: FLOKI
dialogues.text: It’s ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The finished boat. It is a thing of such indescribable be and latent power that Ragnar strokes the burnished planks with his hands and lays his cheek against it, and shivers Freshly oiled and painted. Sinuous, sleek, graceful the h rising shapely, like the contours of a body, like an orga living thing. And the prow standing proud, with its ornately carved dra head. Floki stares intently at Ragnar, watching his reactions. Ragnar looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: It’s... Floki puts a finger over his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: FLOKI
dialogues.text: No need to say. I see it in your eyes. (beat) Let’s put her on the water.  57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Floki, his assistant, Ragnar and Rollo pull and heave the finished boat, over wooden rollers, the short distance to water. The boat glides into the water and the men climb in. Threading oars through the oarports they row the boat out into the deeper waters of the fyord, where a strong breez ripples the surface and sends the clouds scudding across sky. Floki is like a man possessed, grunting and groaning, sighing, swearing at, then encouraging the boat, listenin intently to its creakings, watching for its listing. Ragnar ships his oar.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Now the sail, Floki, the sail!

dialogues.speaker: FLOKI
dialogues.text: She'll sink. Oh, what have I done?

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: No she won’t. She won’t sink.

dialogues.speaker: FLOKI
dialogues.text: I shouldn’t have pretended to build such a boat. It’s beyond my humble capabilities. I’m a fool. He looks as if he’s about to cry.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: I’1ll set the sail. Ragnar unfurls the large black sail. It falls. The others fasten the ropes. Nothing happens for a moment. The sail flaps rather uselessly.

dialogues.speaker: FLOKI
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Ragnar. I’ve wasted all your money. It was all a joke.

dialogues.speaker: RAGNAR
dialogues.text: Shut up, man. A beat.  58.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLO
dialogues.text: Look! A breeze catches the sail and it swells out proudly. The starts to move. As it moves faster, the motion stabilizes becomes less choppy. It glides on smoothly, still picking speed. And now, suddenly, they’re flying! The boat, still sittin low in the water, cuts through it so easily that the fram doesn’t shudder on impact with the waves. It seems to rid over the waves. And, after a while, there’s an eruption of joy inside the boat, the men shouting, and hugging, and Floki going mad, laughing, leaping about, hugging them, trailing his hands the water.

dialogues.speaker: FLOKI
dialogues.text: Ha! What did I tell you? Now it runs on its cool keel. It’s beautiful. Why didn’t you believe me? Then, as they speed on, they calm down. Sober up. Look at shoreline racing past. Ragnar doesn’t say anything. He doesn’t need to, his expression says it all. He can see the future now. He is sitting on the edge of his dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HORSEMAN sits astride his horse, at the edge of the cli and watches the black-sailed ship carving through the wav We have seen him before. He has a livid scar that joins h mouth to his eye. He is one of Earl Haraldson’s housecarl He stares as the boat flies on.
